segments.text: Okay, 17 February 2000, Nick Bazbanes at home in Grafton with Neil Griffin from London.

It's a nice kind of thing.
Okay, we're up and running now.
I would suggest the best thing to do would be for me to start because that will be shorter.
So, if I talk a little bit about my meeting with Jim Casper,
You can cross the ground with me on that, and, you know, for additional information on that.
Okay.
But for the purposes of my tape, I know who Hedman O'Moore is, but perhaps you could explain who Jim Casper is.
Yeah, Jim Casper is a man now in his, I would estimate, early 40s.
He lived in Newton, in Massachusetts.
He was a student at Brandeis University, contemporaneous, with David Waxman.

and michael davis who was a student of haven o'more's um courses which were conducted off campus for reasons we'll get into later and also sold um products from the shackley pyramid selling so he was which was which was happening um contemporaneously in fact um was an intrinsic part of the course and remind me later on
about Shagli because I do have some documentation on it.
Okay.
He was a filmmaker.

Which we will be watching presently.
We will.
And it's a 35 minute one man show featuring pretty much yoga and only yoga.
He was also
sent up to North Dakota and Montana to make a movie for Haven No More.
Oh, that's new.

Yeah, to make a movie for Haven No More about, well, it was essentially about man and his relationship with Earth, but the environment in which it was being made was a union dispute, a labor dispute, and an environmental dispute with coal mining, coal and oil mining companies.
who were strip-mining the area under conditions of great secrecy.
And Jim Casper was sent off by Haven and was making a documentary about this.
I think... We don't have to go off on this.
No, but I think Haven's involvement in this was that he saw an opportunity to use this subject matter as a way of making a film about the ideal relationship between man and earth.
The movie did actually get made under...

very extreme conditions jim casper tells me and with very little money and he was actually infuriated later when he realized that michael davis was a multi-millionaire he had no inkling every time they were both at brandeis and that i even know more had access to this money let me get this straight uh he met davis at brandeis um casper knew of davis's existence but brett davis whether you know it or not went to harvard

At the courses for Shackley.

while he was a student at Harvard.

And he disappeared.
He went away to school.
I said, where did he go to school?
She didn't know.
I mean, had she said everything?
It would have been so easy.
Why, you know, why it never occurred to me that this kid was at Harvard?
You know, it really does answer a lot of questions, by the way.
I mean, a lot of things now fit.

He didn't understand that?
No matter what Casper said to him, he couldn't get it into his head that with the extra money, once the film had been finished properly and blocked off and everything,
you know, the film would look the way a film should.
Maybe it didn't glorify him in ways of the right of life.
O' Moore didn't say that, and Casper didn't either, but the implication was there.
It's possible that the movie he returned from North Dakota that O' Moore had envisaged.
And the result was that O' Moore washed his hands a bit.
No further money was forthcoming to complete the movie.
And this was 1974, right?
Yeah, O' Moore took the print.
Very interesting time period.
Caspar hasn't seen it since.
He hasn't seen it since.
So, but I don't think this is a matter of some... Nope, this is just... It's peripheral.
It's peripheral, I think, yeah.
Spearing everything.

The falling out was over what Caspar saw as Waxman's slavish devotion to her mother.

Waxman was surprised to hear that I was going to meet her more.
but still wanted to wait until O'Maw had met me.
He's terrified of O'Maw.
Yeah.
Still wanted to wait until O'Maw had met me to, um, decide whether or not he wanted to do something.
I mean, there's a fascinating little, there's a fascinating little story to Gentle Madness involving, uh, uh, David Laxman.
Uh, those who own the, the uncorrected page, the, the, the galleys of my book, it's a pretty, a pretty interesting thing to own.
I can certainly show it to you.
But in the first draft, which Waxman got a copy of, I don't know, we don't really know how, but I know how.
I'll see you through the original.
Thank you very much.
You're welcome.
Thank you.
Thanks.
Okay, and then if you'd like to make a copy, you may have the answer.
Waxman had confirmed to me that Haven O'Moore's name originally was Haven Moore.
And that Haven O'Moore was a play on Have No More.
And he did that on tape, and I wrote that into the book.
When he got his hands on a copy of The Galleys, he went crazy.
He went ballistic.
He called my editor, he put in this, he put in that.
I was quoted out of context.
I never said this.
This is impossible.
I'm going to sue.
He would fuck his bad brains think he is.
I mean, you know, he's a quote.
I said, really now, really now, let's take it easy.
And then I really, really,
lacerated my editor's ass for letting copies of the proof get out, you know?
I mean, I said, there's some fiery stuff in here.
We really don't want the world getting your hands on it before we're in print.
Anyway, he said, why don't you talk to Waxman and work this out?
We're concerned here.
I said, fine.
I called Waxman on the phone.
He said, well, Mr. Baxter, David, before you say a word, I said, before you say a word, I said, let me play something for you, okay?
And so I played the tape recording of our telephone.
And he said, did you tape this?
I said, well, of course I did.
And I did it with your permission.
I did.
OK?
I did.
He doesn't remember that, but I did.
And I had work.
I said, now that we understand that I'm not misquoting it, and that I have my facts straight, I said, what's the problem now?
I said, it is so important for me not to have that go in your book.
He didn't want to be the one.
I said, well, you know what, my dad, David, I said, is that it?
Is that the biggest problem here?
He said, I'd like everything out of the book.
I said, well, guess what?
I said, that's not going to happen.
I said, you knew you were talking to a writer when he spoke.
I said, you knew you were being interviewed for a publication.
And I said, I've got you on tape, and I will use material that is pertinent to the book.
But, however, if this is something, I said, but having said that, now let's find out what the problem is and maybe we can lessen the blow.
He said, what he really did not want is his confirming the Haven War thing.
I said, is that it?
He said, yeah.
I said, fine, it's out.
I'm taking it out.
He said, you're going to do that?
I said, yeah.
I said, because, you know what?
I said, David, trust me, it's not because I'm such a nice guy.
I said, because I have confirmation from the federal government.
I've got it in their document.
An official communication in response to a freedom of information at query.
I said, confirming on the strength of a social security number, which is authentic, which I passed on to them, and they'd say the name he used when he was in the U.S.
Army was even more.
I said, so I don't need David Wacken.
But later...
You see, I think that this was a, then when the stuff came from Haven, he was denying that this was him, that I must have the wrong guy, not knowing that I knew about the Kansas thing.

If I don't have that deposition, Neil, I am, I mean, in my mind, this thing, I'll show you the letters that came in, that I had fabricated this, I was reckless, I was malicious, I was all of these things.
And if you didn't have the wrong guy, if I had gone into the Army in 1944, I would have only been fifteen years old.
Well, you'll see, you know, in this sworn deposition here, where he says, uh, he was fifteen years old.

A little bit.
Yes, that's a lie, by the way.
Where was that?
In the European theater.
Another lie.

You came back, well, anyway, you see, this is all wrong.
I wandered around here.
When did you go, where did you go when you left home at age 13?
I wandered around for a couple of years and worked at many things and tried to survive and did end, obviously, and then went into the Army.
Would that have been, I'm just, this is a lawyer now, I'm just trying to do some eyeball mathematics.

The early to mid-40s?
When you left around here, it would have been about the 40 years.
Where did you wander?
Oh, I wandered around Oklahoma, and I wandered around Kansas, and I wandered around South Texas.

Fifteen.
Fifteen.
Fifteen.

The Army.

He was in the Army for two and a half years altogether.
But that's total.
When he goes in later, it was Richard H. Moore.
When they found out he was fifteen years old, that explains, you see, now the whole thing makes perfect sense to me.
When they discovered that they had this fifteen-year-old kid in the Army,
They mustered him out.
But, you know, he's not a criminal.
You aren't angry that a young man wants to serve his country in wartime.
You don't make it hard on him.
You allow him to go out under the name by which he came in.
Am I right?
I mean, the documentation shows that.
It was an honorable discharge when they found out his age.
It was an honorable discharge, and that's why he buried the paperwork down in North Carolina.

which he learned from and which he used again, which is why it's so certain, when he was setting up the limited partnership here in Massachusetts and burying the paperwork, and I'm pointing west, 120 miles west of Poughkeepsie.
That's west.

It worked.

When he left to avoid the communist invasion in 1949, he went to Japan and then Korea.

At the time, he says he was selling women's shoes, he was being an elevator boy, he was living on 75 bucks a month.
He took him past exams for direct army commission, he chose the infantry, went to Benning.
where he had infantry training, he said.

forces.

I've got to ignore that.

He says that MacArthur and Willoughby asked him to stay in the army.
He declined even after an offer of promotion to Major.

That's the history of his military service.

For example, the movie was made in 73.
And when you have an opportunity to read the deposition, he will tell you that he went through life
calling himself Haven O'War, when in fact he was really calling himself Haven O'War.
Maybe he was calling himself Haven O'War, but he changed the name legally in 1974 to Haven O'War.
Now I have a theory as to why he did this at that particular time, even though he may well have been calling himself Haven O'War for many years prior to that.
The answer is very simple.
The answer is that he had just met Michael Davis,

And as you will see, when I have the other documents here, when they started doing property transactions, when they started establishing the Dolphin Realty Trucks, when they started establishing the Institute of Traditional Science, which Michael was the principal of.
Michael was the money and all of these things.
Clearly, Haven's name was going to appear on any of these documents.
He wanted it to appear as Haven O'Moore, but the only way he could do that legally is to be named, to be Haven O'Moore.
And so now, even though he had been calling himself by that name for all these years, so he claims
That's when he legally changed the name.
But it was really, I believe, done to expedite the transactions with Davis.

Once Davis had taken that hook, once Haven had seen for the cleanification he had landed, worth millions and millions of dollars, I mean, a con man's greatest dream come true, which is what this guy is.
He's a snake oil sales and so on, Shackley Products.
That's what he is.
What he has now found is Michael Davis, and they set about doing the things that I've documented in that case in Cambridge, which is fully impounded.
You ask if you can go and see these records?
Of course you can.
You should also be able to go to that courthouse and see that case file.
This is egregious.
This violates every law that we have.
Our courts, as are yours, this is not the Stark Chamber.
This is done
in a superior court, and the public has allowed to come in and examine, to observe and to examine.
And they have impounded the whole thing.
Let me pick your brain, American law, or as much as you know about it, because whatever it is, it's going to be more than me.
What steps have to be taken in order to take public documents out of the public domain?
How would this have been done?
You mean to see the records?
No, to prevent other people seeing the records.
How would that case have been taken out of public domain?
I've been an investigative journalist now.
I've been a journalist for 30 years.
I've got a few awards to document my facility.
I've never seen anything like it.
Lawyers I talk to don't believe it.
Another guy called me, another lawyer,
He said he was going to try and see if he could find out about this stuff.
Nobody has ever heard of this.
The fact that you can impound a whole case like that, it's unheard of.
To answer your question, what does it take?
I think it takes money and influence.
That's what it takes.
I'm not suggesting bribery here, but I'm certainly suggesting a tremendous amount of influence by very, very influential people on both sides, plaintiff and defendant,
You see, it was not in the best interest of either side of this dispute to have the differences aired.
Generally speaking, somebody's got an agenda here where it serves my purposes to have this thing come out in the public.
It didn't serve the best interest of the Davises, and it didn't serve the best interest of... I think that's incidental, isn't it?
Because you went along to...
When you were researching the book, a gentleman, you went along to the Middlesex Superior Court to see the records.
You went away, they told you to come back in two weeks or whatever.
When you came back, the whole case had disappeared.
Now, clearly there was great animosity between O'Moore and the Davis family at the time of the case.
I don't believe they colluded in keeping it out of the public.
No, I think they did.
Do you?
Yeah, I can prove it.
I can prove it.
You can prove it, I'll stop talking, because it seems to me that the Davis side of the case... This is now an impounded document.
The day I suspected that there was a case called Davis, individual and as trustee,
We will make you a copy of this.

entered into a stipulation to protect the confidentiality of certain information.
